unnormalised: So, I was wondering, why do prices in India always seem so… specific? Like, you’ll never find anything priced at a nice, round Rs. 100. It's always Rs. 99, Rs. 199, or even the dreaded Rs. 499! Is it some kind of mass retail hypnosis?!
normalised: So, I was wondering, why do prices in India always seem so… specific? Like, you will never find anything priced at a nice, round rupee one hundred. It is always rupee ninety nine, rupee one hundred and ninety nine, or even the dreaded rupee four hundred and ninety nine! Is it some kind of mass retail hypnosis?!

unnormalised: Seriously, though, I've got a theory. Maybe it's some ancient Indian philosophy about never being *quite* satisfied with a purchase? Like, you think you're getting a steal at Rs. 499, but deep down, you know they got you for that extra rupee. Or maybe shopkeepers just REALLY hate dealing with exact change. Imagine the chaos if everyone got back a single, solitary rupee! Auto-rickshaw drivers would be ecstatic, hoarding those tiny coins like Smaug with his gold!

unnormalised: And don’t even get me started on the “special offers” that are perpetually “ending soon.” Like that "Mega Sale" on Flipkart, offering a whopping 20% off... on *selected* items. And of course, the item I want is excluded! It's like they're personally taunting me. I swear, if I see one more "limited time offer" that's been running for six months, I'm going to start my own e-commerce site where everything is exactly Rs. 100. No ifs, ands, or buts.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole “MRP inclusive of all taxes” thing. Which, let's be honest, is a total lie. It's like saying my weight includes all the guilt from eating that second samosa. Technically true, but not exactly the whole story. I mean, how else do those chai wallahs survive charging Rs. 10 a cup? They're either secretly backed by Ambani or operating in a tax-free zone unknown to mortal man.

unnormalised: Honestly, I think it's all a grand conspiracy to keep us on our toes. Shopping in India is like a mental workout. You're constantly calculating discounts, comparing prices, and trying to figure out if that “genuine leather” wallet is actually made of bonded leather scraps. So, next time you see something priced at Rs. 399, just remember, you're not just buying a product, you're participating in a centuries-old tradition of retail shenanigans. Enjoy!
